Issues.Title: [NGCC] Permit publishing Ivy compiled packages | Micro Frontends
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request ### Relevant Package This feature request is for @angular/compiler-cli ### Description Currently when compiling with Ivy enabled, the resulting libraries contain a `prepublishOnly` lifecycle script to prevent the publication of the package. E.g.
```JSON "prepublishOnly": "node --eval \"console.error('ERROR: Trying to publish a package that has been compiled by Ivy. This is not allowed.\\nPlease delete and rebuild the package, without compiling with Ivy, before attempting to publish.\\n')\" && exit 1" ``` ### Describe the solution you'd like We are successfully establishing the [Micro Frontend approach with angular](https://github.com/flash-me/angular-micro-frontends) at our client side for every new project (company > 8000 employees). Angular 9.0.6 included already fixes ([details](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/35429#issuecomment-600202556)) so I could remove the needed workarounds to implement Micro Frontends with pure angular toolchain. The customer I'm working for provides an Artifactory with a custom NPM registry, where all the Micro Frontend Packages are hosted. **We are already working with Ivy compiled "libraries"**. It would be nice to have a flag with which we could disable the inclution of that `prepublishOnly` script. Something like ```JSON "angularCompilerOptions": { "permitPublication": "true" } ``` or at the `ngcc` level by a flag like `--permitPublishing` ### Describe alternatives you've considered To enable the automatic (CI/CD) publication of those packages (to the internal artifactory), I worked this around by including following line in the Pipeline to remove the `prepublishOnly` script from the `package.json`: ```bash sed -i '/prepublishOnly/d' package.json ``` No rocket science... but still a workaround. Anyway it would be nice to know, when you consider Ivy Libraries to be "stable" for publication. cheers flash :zap:
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NGCC] Permit publishing Ivy compiled packages | Micro Frontends" (#36195)

# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages as the source of the bug? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: --> The issue is caused by package @angular/compiler, @angular/language-service


### Is this a regression?

<!-- Did this behavior use to work in the previous version? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> No
### Description

Please support type guard in Template, like jsx in react.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

```ts
@Component({
  selector: 'my-app',
  template: `
    <ng-container *ngIf="value.hasDisplayName; else elseTemplate">
      {{ value.displayName }}
    </ng-container>
    <ng-template #elseTemplate>
      {{ value.name }}
    </ng-template>
  `,
  // Identifier 'displayName' is not defined. '{ readonly hasDisplayName: true; readonly displayName: string; } | { readonly hasDisplayName: false; readonly name: string; }' does not contain such a member
  // Identifier 'name' is not defined. '{ readonly hasDisplayName: true; readonly displayName: string; } | { readonly hasDisplayName: false; readonly name: string; }' does not contain such a member
})
export class AppComponent {
  readonly value:
    | { readonly hasDisplayName: true; readonly displayName: string }
    | { readonly hasDisplayName: false; readonly name: string } = {
    hasDisplayName: true,
    displayName: 'Foo',
  };
}
```

---

We always use discriminated union for define our data models.

There is the list of type guard we used frequently:

* instanceof type guards
* typeof type guards
* user-defined type guards
* key in type guard ( `'somekey' in someobject ? someobject.somekey : someobject.other`)

These features are very important for us to convert the data model defined in *the nodejs server code and existing react code* to Angular code.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[language service] support type guard in template" (#36192)

Issues.Title: [language service] support ReadonlyArray and tuple in ngFor
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/compiler, @angular/language-service ### Is this a regression? No ### Description Only Array are supported in ngFor by current language service. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ```ts @Component({ selector: 'my-app', template: `
{{ item }}
`, // (variable) item: any }) export class AppComponent { items = [{ name: 'foo' }, { name: 'bar' }] as const; } ``` If we remove `as const`: ```ts @Component({ selector: 'my-app', template: `
{{ item }}
`, // (variable) item: { name: string; } }) export class AppComponent { items = [{ name: 'foo' }, { name: 'bar' }]; } ``` If we change it into ReadonlyArray: ```ts @Component({ selector: 'my-app', template: `
{{ item }}
`, // (variable) item: any }) export class AppComponent { items: ReadonlyArray<{ name: string }> = [{ name: 'foo' }, { name: 'bar' }]; } ```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[language service] support ReadonlyArray and tuple in ngFor" (#36191)

Issues.Title: [REQUEST] isProdMode or best practices to share environment variables with lib modules
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages the are relevant for this feature request? -->
This feature request is for @angular/core

### Description
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> A clear and concise description of the problem or missing capability...
Yeah, here is the problem.
I have multi project:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16970990/77238831-7793cd00-6c06-11ea-882e-df1f49afff0b.png)
And then instead of having 2 * 4 = 8 enviroment file duplicate for firebase information:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16970990/77238853-b164d380-6c06-11ea-8452-c25a38b4ac2d.png)
I really want to create only one module like this to easy import firebase module once (instead of 4 times):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16970990/77238873-01dc3100-6c07-11ea-84ac-1339c9651f57.png)
but since `isDevMode` is calling in my firebase module, and it is call before enableProdMode() calling out. so I got this error
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16970990/77238885-1f10ff80-6c07-11ea-8ac5-8ca4d8849830.png)
and even more, we can do tree sakeable module:

```
@NgModule({
  declarations: [
    AppComponent
  ],
  imports: [
    BrowserModule,
    AppRoutingModule,
    isProdMode() ? [] : DevModule,
  ],
  providers: [],
  bootstrap: [AppComponent]
})
export class AppModule { }

```

### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.
somekindof `isProdMode()` which is can read enviroment file quickly. Doesn't have to wait `main.ts` 
That can be useful for reading `prod` mode from library. Or multi project workspace.
### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?
```
// environment.prod.ts 
(global as any).prod = true;
```

```
// firebase.module.ts
console.log('isProd??', (global as any).prod);
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[REQUEST] isProdMode or best practices to share environment variables with lib modules" (#36190)

Issues.Title: Navigating to lazy loaded module from route guard causes the URL path to briefly be blank
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/router ### Is this a regression? Not sure ### Description If you have a page that is protected by a route guard which triggers a redirect (thus cancelling the current navigation) to a page which is lazy-loaded, the URL will briefly read just the host name (`/`) while the module loads. (An example of this would be having a dashboard that's protected by a user login guard that redirects to the login page (which in my case is lazy-loaded).) This is further an issue because it changes the history so that if the user hits the back button, they will be taken to `/` rather than the page they originally tried to navigate to. Also, if there is a network issue retrieving the module, the user will be abandoned on the home page. If they refresh to try to fix the issue, they will no longer be where they started. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction [angular-lazy-load-guard-test.zip](https://github.com/angular/angular/files/4363701/angular-lazy-load-guard-test.zip) Navigate to `/page1` and you should get redirected to `/page2`. However, notice that the URL briefly reads `/`. If this is not apparent, try adding network throttling (a Firefox feature) to slow down the retrieval of the lazy module. I also have a second redirect that emulates the behavior of the guard in the Page1Component. If you disable the card, the page1 component will still redirect. *However*, note that the URL never reads blank at this point...it always shows something. ## üî• Exception or Error N/A ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 9.0.7
Node: 12.3.1
OS: linux x64

Angular: 9.0.7
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

-----------------------------------------------------------

@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.900.7

Issues.Title: Error NG6002: Upgraded LIB to NG9
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package There is a similar problem https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/35536 and if I follow instructions from this issue it works as a workaround ### Is this a regression? Yes. NG8 has no problem compiling local libs and local app to test it. ### Description As you can see it here at [MetaUI](https://github.com/ngx-meta/rules/tree/ng9), I have `libs` and `apps` folders. **Libs** contains two libraries ( that we shoudl care about now): - **rules** - core rules engine library - **material-rules** - Specific UI library implementation for rules. It also uses and imports core `rules` library Then I have **apps** as playground: - **material-app**: which imports both libraries. The normal workflow in NG8 to be able to test `material-app` was: ``` ng build rules ng build material-rules ng build material-app ng serve material-app ``` Now `ng build material-app` fails with **NG6002 & NG6003** errors. But if I follow #35536, and run ` npx ngcc && ngcc -s dist` before building `material-app`, all works. so Running: ``` rm -Rf dist && ng build rules && ng build material-rules && npx ngcc && ngcc -s dist ng build material-app ``` fixes problem ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ``` git clone -b ng9 https://github.com/ngx-meta/rules.git cd rules/ npm install // Now you can run to see errors rm -Rf dist && ng build rules && ng build material-rules && ng build material-app // run to fix it rm -Rf dist && ng build rules && ng build material-rules && npx ngcc && ngcc -s dist ng build material-app ``` ## üî• Exception or Error 


ERROR in dist/libs/rules/lib/metaui/rules.module.d.ts:27:22 - error NG6002: Appears in the NgModule.imports of MetaUILibLayoutModule, but could not be resolved to an NgModule class.

This likely means that the dependency (@ngx-metaui/rules) which declares MetaUIRulesModule has not been processed correctly by ngcc.

27 export declare class MetaUIRulesModule {
                        ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
libs/material-rules/src/lib/metaui/meta-ui-layout.module.ts:71:14 - error NG6002: Appears in the NgModule.imports of MaterialRulesModule, but itself has errors

71 export class MetaUILibLayoutModule {
                ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
dist/libs/rules/lib/metaui/rules.module.d.ts:27:22 - error NG6002: Appears in the NgModule.imports of AppModule, but could not be resolved to an NgModule class.

This likely means that the dependency (@ngx-metaui/rules) which declares MetaUIRulesModule has not been processed correctly by ngcc.

27 export declare class MetaUIRulesModule {
                        ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
libs/material-rules/src/lib/material-rules.module.ts:40:14 - error NG6002: Appears in the NgModule.imports of AppModule, but itself has errors

40 export class MaterialRulesModule {

Issues.Title: fix(ngcc): use path-mappings from tsconfig in dependency resolution
Issues.Body:
When computing the dependencies between packages which are not in
node_modules, we may need to rely upon path-mappings to find the path
to the imported entry-point.

This commit allows ngcc to use the path-mappings from a tsconfig
file to find dependencies. By default any tsconfig.json file in the directory
above the `basePath` is loaded but it is possible to use a path to a
specific file by providing the `tsConfigPath` property to mainNgcc,
or to turn off loading any tsconfig file by setting `tsConfigPath` to `null`.
At the command line this is controlled via the `--tsconfig` option.

Fixes #36119
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ngcc): use path-mappings from tsconfig in dependency resolution" (#36180)

Issues.Title: docs: Change definition of NgModules in Angular concepts guide
Issues.Body:
My perception when working with the Angular framework is that it is component oriented. Thus, the basic building block should be the component. NgModules help us to organize our components and other Angular artifacts into separate functional domains easier.

Also with the advent of Ivy compiler, we may be able to render module-less components https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/1c85c24ed3ef7d220bf2de9f2cf8b08556547ff9/integration/cli-hello-world-ivy-minimal/src/main.ts in the future.

Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Description I'm finally getting around to using ```angularCompilerOptions``` and have started to use ```fullTemplateCheck```. It seems as if while checking the templates, there is a failure to see the ```+``` unary operator in front of the ```hours``` variable (```hours``` is a string). The ```+``` turns the string into a number so I believe this is an incorrect error, and therefore a bug? Also it seems like ```fullTemplateCheck``` is incorrectly handing ```==```, as it incorrectly states that the result will always return false in the second code snippet below. ## üî• Exception or Error Unary: 
error TS2362: The left-hand side of an arithmetic operation must be of type 'any', 'number', 'bigint' or an enum type.
<div (click)="formatHours(+hours + 1)">
Doulble Equals: 
error TS2367: This condition will always return 'false' since the types 'string' and 'number' have no overlap.
<div [ngClass]="{'disabled': displayHours == 23}">
## Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 9.0.4
Node: 10.16.1
OS: linux x64

Angular: 9.0.4
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

-----------------------------------------------------------

@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.900.4

Issues.Title: IE11 only: blur and multiple focus events sent for animated elements' children
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package 3 different packages are involved in the issue: @angular/animations, the package containing ng-container, and the package defining structural directives. ### Is this a regression? No ### Description Focusing on a child element in a very specific configuration will cause the intended focus to be triggered, followed by a blur, followed by a second iteration of the intended focus. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction I created [a Github repository](https://github.com/jzabinski/multipleEventsOnFocus) for the problem since Stackblitz doesn't seem to run in IE11. To reproduce: 1. Clone the repository. 2. 'npm install' 3. 'ng serve' 4. Open IE11, and navigate to https://localhost:4200. 5. Open IE11's Developer Tools 6. Click the text 'Click this to make a button appear' appearing on the page. Watch the console, and you should see three messages: 'button focused' 'button blurred, currently active element: BODY' 'button focused' ## üî• Exception or Error Not applicable ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 



Angular CLI: 9.0.7
Node: 12.13.1
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 9.0.7
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Package                           Version
-----------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect         0.900.7
@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.900.7
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer   0.900.7
@angular-devkit/build-webpack     0.900.7
@angular-devkit/core              9.0.7
@angular-devkit/schematics        9.0.7
@ngtools/webpack                  9.0.7
@schematics/angular               9.0.7
@schematics/update                0.900.7
rxjs                              6.5.4
typescript                        3.7.5
webpack                           4.41.2
**Anything else relevant?** This happens in IE11 only: version 11.657.18362.0. If you try the steps to reproduce in Chrome or Edge, you will only get a message saying 'button focused'. Very important detail: this behavior only occurs in the following template setup: ```
``` So you need: 1. A parent ng-container using an *ngIf to determine whether to display 2. A child element using an animation 3. A child ng-container receiving an ngTemplateOutlet Then if a ViewChild is used to focus on the button in IE11, you will get an extra blur and another focus. Taking away any of those three factors removes the ability to reproduce the issue.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "IE11 only: blur and multiple focus events sent for animated elements' children" (#36175)

Issues.Title: Ivy is not complaining about unknown element inside ng-template
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Description
Ivy does not complain about an unknown element when this element is placed inside `ng-template`. When it's outside of `ng-template` it throws a build error.

The issue can only be found in runtime (no component being rendered) or with `fullTemplateTypeCheck: true`.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

1. Create a new Angular app, open the `tsconfig.json` and update `angularCompilerOptions`  to
```json
  "angularCompilerOptions": {
    "enableIvy": true
  }
```
2. open `app.component.html` and update its content to:
```
<ng-container *ngTemplateOutlet="test1"></ng-container>

<ng-template #test1>
   <some-component></some-component>
</ng-template>
```
3. Run `ng serve` and observe no build errors (<---- Issue here)
4. open `tsconfig.json` and update `angularCompilerOptions` to:
```
  "angularCompilerOptions": {
    "enableIvy": false
  }
```
5. Run `ng serve` and observe a build error
6. Open the `tsconfig.json` and update `angularCompilerOptions`  to
```json
  "angularCompilerOptions": {
    "enableIvy": true
  }
```
7. open `app.component.html` and update its content to:
```
<ng-container *ngTemplateOutlet="test1"></ng-container>
<some-component></some-component>

<ng-template #test1>
   <some-component></some-component>
</ng-template>
```
8. Run `ng serve` and observe a build error

## üåç  Your Environment

**Angular Version:** 9.0.7


Please clarify if the discrepancy in the compiler behavior between steps `3` and `5` or `8` is an intended behavior.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Ivy is not complaining about unknown element inside ng-template" (#36171)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): update babel to 7.8.7
Issues.Body:
Babel versions 7.8.0-7.8.6 contain a defect that can cause failures due to babel plugin changes (even in patch versions).  Plugins are not pinned as they are transitive dependencies of the packages adjusted in this commit.  This failure will prevent a newly generated project from building and can only be worked around by disabling differential loading.

Fixes: #17262

Issues.Title: Allow directTemplateLoading to be set from angular.json or webpack configuration
Issues.Body:
Reopening https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/15861
# üöÄ Feature request

Command (mark with an x)
- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [x] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

## Description
The AngularCompilerPlugin allows templates to be loaded directly, bypassing any loaders configured in the webpack config. The default value of this option is false.

The Angular CLI creates an instance of the AngularCompilerPlugin and sets this option to true, with no way of overriding this behavior.

Setting this to true made sense when there was no way to customize the webpack config. However, now that CLI Builders are officially supported, it will become more common for builders like @angular-builders/custom-webpack to be used to customize the webpack configuration. But with directTemplateLoading being hard-coded to true, there is no way to customize the webpack configuration to allow a loader to manipulate a component's template.

## Describe the solution you'd like
Let the directTemplateLoading option be set in the angular.json file. For example:

"architect": {
  "build": {
    "builder": "@angular-builders/custom-webpack:browser",
    "options": {
      "directTemplateLoading": false,
      "customWebpackConfig": {
        "path": "./webpack.config.js"
      },
      "etc": "etc"

## Describe alternatives you've considered

These are outlined in https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/15861
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Allow directTemplateLoading to be set from angular.json or webpack configuration" (#17265)

Issues.Title: `jit-prod` test is failing CI
Issues.Body:
CI is failing on most branches and blocking RC. https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/angular/angular-cli/6157/workflows/14f7b0bd-d3d5-442c-ae94-56d2a6eed305/jobs/146745

I started some preliminary investigation and am able to reproduce by running:

```
node ./tests/legacy-cli/run_e2e --debug
```

There is a glob argument to choose the offending test and run just that, but I can't seem to get it to work. This pauses when the test fails and keeps the temporary directory where it ran open.

Going into that directory, `ng e2e --prod` fails, which is what CI is trying to run. This appears to be testing the example `ng new` app prod build after setting `aot` and `buildOptimizer` to `false`.

https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/tests/legacy-cli/e2e/tests/build/jit-prod.ts

Changing either setting or running without `--prod` passes the test, so it appears to be coming from this specific set of options.

Running `ng serve --prod` and visiting the app I can see the full error:

```
ERROR ReferenceError: Cannot access 's' before initialization
    at Function.get (main.81a14e60f5c105102a14.js:formatted:16209)
    at $t (main.81a14e60f5c105102a14.js:formatted:7246)
    at nf.resolveComponentFactory (main.81a14e60f5c105102a14.js:formatted:14342)
    at Dv.bootstrap (main.81a14e60f5c105102a14.js:formatted:17062)
    at main.81a14e60f5c105102a14.js:formatted:16955
    at Array.forEach (<anonymous>)
    at Tv._moduleDoBootstrap (main.81a14e60f5c105102a14.js:formatted:16955)
    at main.81a14e60f5c105102a14.js:formatted:16939
    at u.invoke (polyfills.f95e9862a91f7a581a3b.js:1)
    at Object.onInvoke (main.81a14e60f5c105102a14.js:formatted:16552)
```

Jumping to place in the code and formatting nicely I see:

```javascript
Object.defineProperty(e, Ve, {
                get: ()=>{
                    if (null === n) {
                        const r = je();
                        if (ul(t)) {
                            const n = [`Component '${e.name}' is not resolved:`];
                            throw t.templateUrl && n.push(` - templateUrl: ${t.templateUrl}`),
                            t.styleUrls && t.styleUrls.length && n.push(` - styleUrls: ${JSON.stringify(t.styleUrls)}`),
                            n.push("Did you run and wait for 'resolveComponentResources()'?"),
                            new Error(n.join("\n"))
                        }
                        const s = s;  // <-------------------- ERROR: Cannot access 's' before initialization
                        let i = t.preserveWhitespaces;
                        void 0 === i && (i = null !== s && void 0 !== s.preserveWhitespaces && s.preserveWhitespaces);
                        let o = t.encapsulation;
                        void 0 === o && (o = null !== s && void 0 !== s.defaultEncapsulation ? s.defaultEncapsulation : At.Emulated);

// ...
```

This appears to be the compiled form of [this line](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/fb92f5de1adc8dccbb947a09b34cb1bcc6b41e7f/packages/core/src/render3/jit/directive.ts#L72) which is throwing the error. The source file looks reasonable to me.

I'm pretty sure this optimized format is just wrong. I don't see any scenario where `const <identifier> = <same identifier>;` would be valid.

```javascript
const foo = 'test';
if (true) {
  const foo = foo; // ReferenceError: Cannot access 'foo' before initialization
}
```

I'm not sure how to debug this further, but it seems to be a prod optimization issue when `buildOptimizer`/`aot` is disabled.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "`jit-prod` test is failing CI" (#17264)

Issues.Title: Base href overridden by locale config
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? This is a potential regression, as the issue occurred after migration from angular v8 to angular v9. There might be however a way to configure i18n framework somehow to omit it. ### Description Prior to angular v9, localization did not impact the `baseHref`. Currently, such a tag is always added to the `index.html`. ```html ``` Previously we did not use it at all to easily allow deploying the application on sub-paths, such as `example.com/kubernetes-dashboard`. This worked without any issues. Right now it will not work due to this tag which we cannot omit. We want the localized build to be selected by the backend based on `Accept-Language` header instead of `/` path. That's why our requirement is to have all requests coming from the same base path. This is our [angular.json](https://github.com/kubernetes/dashboard/blob/master/angular.json#L11). Right now, it has to define `/` as `baseHref` to avoid `/` path logic. Configuring dynamic `baseHref` based on a path is not an option right now as any changes to `base` tag in `index.html` are overridden during the build. Is there any way to avoid adding `base` tag during the build, but still build localized version of the application, or somehow make `baseHref` build final path as a relative path and not as an absolute path? ## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Body:
feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): show warnings when depending on CommonJS.

Depending on CommonJS modules is know to cause optimization bailouts. With this change when running a browser build and scripts optimization is enabled we display a warning.

To suppress the warning for a particular package, users can use the `allowedCommonJsDepedencies` builder options.

Example:
```
"build": {
  "builder": "@angular-devkit/build-angular:browser",
  "options": {
    ...
    "allowedCommonJsDepedencies": ["bootstrap"]
  },
}
```

Reference: TOOL-1328
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): show warnings when depending on CommonJS" (#17250)

Hard to tell as build-dependencies changed from Angular v5 to Angular v6 / v7, right? Building the original v5 application using `ng build --prod --build-optimizer=true` spit out a working application at least. ### Description Building itself works but when trying to launch the application in the browser, an error is logged to the console: ``` main.8cc841c62bc65dc4efeb.js:1 Uncaught TypeError: (intermediate value)(intermediate value) is not a function at main.8cc841c62bc65dc4efeb.js:1 at Object.RCq4.e.exports.12.../apply (main.8cc841c62bc65dc4efeb.js:1) at i (main.8cc841c62bc65dc4efeb.js:1) at main.8cc841c62bc65dc4efeb.js:1 at main.8cc841c62bc65dc4efeb.js:1 at main.8cc841c62bc65dc4efeb.js:1 at Object.RCq4.e.exports.32../lib/Promise (main.8cc841c62bc65dc4efeb.js:1) at i (main.8cc841c62bc65dc4efeb.js:1) at main.8cc841c62bc65dc4efeb.js:1 at Object.RCq4.e.exports.1.../callbacks (main.8cc841c62bc65dc4efeb.js:1) ``` When setting `buildOptimizer` to `false`, everything works out as expected (no error is logged and application launches). ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Check out https://github.com/ClemensSchneider/angular-buildoptimizer-bug/tree/angular7 (or https://github.com/ClemensSchneider/angular-buildoptimizer-bug/tree/angular6 for the Angular v6 version). Issues.Title: bug(MatAutocomplete): Drop-down list is not shown if options are rendered over ng-container with ngTemplateOutlet.
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://stackblitz.com/fork/components-issue

Steps to reproduce:
1. https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-bws6ya
mat-autocomplete is filled with options over observable.
<mat-option> elements are provided inside <ng-container *ngIf="(entryCategories$ | _async_) as entryCategories">
over <ng-container *ngTemplateOutlet="subCategories; context: { elements: elements} the options won't be shown as a drop-down list.
The full example is provided here: https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-bws6ya
 
#### Expected Behavior

The options should be shown in a drop-down list

#### Actual Behavior

The drop-down list is not rendered.

--------------------

First analysis has shown, that the drop-down-listis rendered with CSS class "mat-autocomplete-hidden", although the options are all rendered. 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6615495/77257872-41426600-6c77-11ea-9078-b6d856a51698.png)

Deeper analysis has shown, that the value for variable in ng-container is gotten later as the  ngAfterContentInit() of MatAutocomplete will be processed. So the value of options from  @ContentChildren(MatOption, {descendants: true}) options: QueryList<MatOption>; is empty. Further so it will be set a CSS class on drop-down list to hide it.
I would suggest to use here this.options.changes as observable of changes in a list of options.

#### Environment

- Angular: 9
- CDK/Material: 9 
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(MatAutocomplete): Drop-down list is not shown if options are rendered over ng-container with ngTemplateOutlet." (#18887)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-tab-group): inner div cannot cover 100% of viewport, on iphone
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://stackblitz.com/fork/components-issue
StackBlitz to reproduce: 
https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-dssxxk
or
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-3qr9lv

Attention - this will reproduce only on iOS (e.g. iPhone) with both Chrome and Safari.
On Android it works perfectly.
On computer with Chrome and F12 on - it works perfectly.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create mat-tab-group with few mat-tab children.
2. Inside one of the children, set a div with 100% height, 100% width, fixed position, with top, right equal to zero and a high z-index. Also, set it with a background-color (e.g. blue) to easily reproduce the behavior.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?
The created div should cover ALL viewport (top to bottom, right to left), including the mat-tab, mat-tab-group and any other components on the HTML page (e.g. navbar etc.)
In other words - all screen will be blue.

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?
The created div covers the entire page, but you cannot see it, although it has a blue background, the blue color appears only within the mat-tab. above the mat-tab it doesn't show the blue background, yet it covers the elements (e.g. if you have a button above the mat-tab-group, you cannot click it)



#### Environment

- Angular: 8
- CDK/Material: 8
- Browser(s): chrome, safari
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): iOS
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(mat-tab-group): inner div cannot cover 100% of viewport, on iphone" (#18883)

Issues.Body:
‚Ä¶to initialize _hoveredContentStateDistinct observable.

It is possible that the _hoveredContentStateDistinct observable is subscribed to after the first emission from editingOrFocused. Issues.Title: fr(MatIconRegistry): Support fetching icons with credentials
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

Right now it seems when you call addSvgIcon, the fetch is done without credentials. This is usually what you want, but unfortunately for cross-domain requests, it can also lead to a client cert being omitted in an environment where client certificates are required. In some cases, Chrome will send the client certificate anyways, but Firefox will not. See whatwg/fetch#869 and the [Chromium issue](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=775438) for background. 

#### Use Case

This would allow SVG icons to be fetched cross-domain in environments where security credentials are required.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "fr(MatIconRegistry): Support fetching icons with credentials" (#18871)

#### What troubleshooting steps have you tried?

On the production build the datepicker language is always English instead of German :(

#### Reproduction

I don't think I can replicate this using StackBlitz since is a production build only issue.. sorry

Steps to reproduce:

```
const DEFAULT_DATE_FORMAT = 'DD.MM.YYYY';
const MY_DATE_FORMATS = {
  parse: {
    dateInput: DEFAULT_DATE_FORMAT,
    backend: 'YYYY-MM-DD',
  },
  display: {
    dateInput: DEFAULT_DATE_FORMAT,
    monthYearLabel: 'MMM YYYY',
    dateA11yLabel: DEFAULT_DATE_FORMAT,
    monthYearA11yLabel: 'MMM YYYY',
  },
};

@NgModule({
  declarations: [...SHARED_COMPONENTS],
  imports: [
    ...
    MatDatepickerModule,
    MatNativeDateModule,
  ],
  providers: [
    {
      provide: MAT_DATE_LOCALE,
      useValue: 'de-ch',
    },
    {
      provide: DateAdapter,
      useClass: MomentDateAdapter,
      deps: [MAT_DATE_LOCALE],
    },
    {
      provide: MAT_DATE_FORMATS,
      useValue: MY_DATE_FORMATS,
    },
  ],
```

2. `npx http-server`

#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?

Users are getting disorientated when the screen scrolls and their text moves, so the screen should not scroll

#### Environment

- Angular: v9.0.7
- CDK/Material: v9.1.3
- Browser(s): Chrome 80
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(cdkTextareaAutosize): Screen scrolls when deleting a character in a text area without cdkAutosizeMaxRows" (#18862)

Issues.Title: bug(MatSelectionList): FormControl bindings return empty result after updating list of options
Issues.Body:
When using FormControl with MatSelectionList, FormControl sometimes report incorrect value.

If the list of options gets updated, FormControl value becomes an empty list instead of current value.

Slightly related: on every value change, FormControl.valueChanges is emitting twice.

#### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Go to https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ps7iuz
2. Click "Mimic server update" button
 
 
#### Expected Behavior
Number of options selected is 1, FormControl value should also report one option is selected.

#### Actual Behavior

FormControl value reports that nothing is selected.

#### Environment

- Angular: 9
- CDK/Material: 9
- Browser(s): all?
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): all?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(MatSelectionList): FormControl bindings return empty result after updating list of options" (#18861)

Issues.Title: bug(material/table): breaks on subsequent data updates if passed null
Issues.Body:
## Bug, enhancement request, or proposal:
Bug report on mat-table

# CodePen and steps to reproduce the issue:

If you don't pass an array as the data source to mat-table, it of course won't be able to show data, HOWEVER, if you later pass it an array of data, *it still* won't work i.e. it breaks until you restart the app or otherwise force the component to reload.

#### Detailed Reproduction Steps: 
I'm using the standard pattern of creating a MatTableDataSource:

dataSource = new MatTableDataSource<any>();
then pulling data from the db and assigning it like so:
this.dataSource.data = data;

As you can see in the stack trace image, i get the error "Cannot read property 'slice' of null as expected:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8941430/76994880-69ebf800-6925-11ea-9689-a9ae616cb3a2.png)

The underlying code in table.js line 861 is as follows:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8941430/76995052-addefd00-6925-11ea-9fbd-6b5ea13a6c11.png)


### What is the expected behavior?
If the data is bad (e.g. null), it should be resilient to display good data when reset.

### What is the current behavior?
Table stops working.

### What is the use-case or motivation for changing an existing behavior?
Even though I have code on the backend to ensure an empty array is passed, due to the complexity of scenarios, its possible the fail-safe code isn't hit and I get a bad result (null, undefined, etc.). On the front-end due to how mat-table behaves, I now have to sanity check the result as well. Ideally the mat-table itself would be resilient / tolerate occasional bad data.

### Which versions of AngularJS, Material, OS, and browsers are affected?
using all latest / greatest as of 3.18.2020, namely:
angular material 9.1.3
angular 9.0.6

- Browsers: 
 latest Chrome
### Is there anything else we should know? Stack Traces, Screenshots, etc.


<!-- Please double check that you have provided the required reproduction steps and a Demo via CodePen, Plunker, or GitHub repo. -->

Hopefully the issue / request is apparent from looking at the stack trace. I don't have a stackblitz to offer at the moment but can work on it if warranted.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(material/table): breaks on subsequent data updates if passed null" (#18858)
